revised_title: Life History Plasticity in Chimaeras of the Colonial Ascidian Botryllus schlosseri
tldr: This study demonstrates that chimaeras of the colonial ascidian Botryllus schlosseri have highly plastic life histories and adapt different strategies based on their environment. In the field, chimaeras grow rapidly, reach large sizes, and produce many eggs, while in the laboratory, they grow slowly, shrink, and fragment. The phenomenon of resorption, where tissues of one genotype are consumed by the other, occurs mainly in the laboratory environment and not in the field. These findings show the importance of understanding life history patterns in chimaeras to predict their evolution and adaptability.
